content.webTitle: Despair of the women inside Western Australia's most overcrowded prison

fields.headline: Despair of the women inside Western Australia's most overcrowded prison
fields.bodyText: Women inside Bandyup, Western Australia’s most overcrowded prison, have written of their frustration and despair at the cramped conditions, with one suggesting that sharing with male prisoners would be better than staying put. A letter written by one inmate and obtained with permission by Guardian Australia said women should be moved into the male-only prison Hakea immediately, rather than waiting more than 12 months for a dividing wall to be built. Poetry written by another inmate described conditions at the prison. She writes: Doors are locked at six-thirty Sleeping on the floor – feels dirty. Toilet just there for two of us to bare So hot in here, causes so much despair. On Monday there were 323 women living at Bandyup, down from a record high of 340 two weeks ago. The ageing facility was built for 220 people but women have been sharing cells to make room, with some sleeping on mattresses on the floor. Most of the prison is not air-conditioned. The corrective services minister, Joe Francis, announced in December that 256 women would be moved to Hakea remand prison, which, like Bandyup, is located in Perth’s suburban fringe, as soon as a dividing wall can be built between the units intended for women and the wider male prison population. But the prisoner’s letter said conditions at Bandyup would reach a “crisis” point by the time the wall was complete. “Some female prisoners cannot safely be doubled up with others because of their history of sexual predation or harming others. Doubling these women up places other prisoners at risk,” the writer said. “The department has a duty of care to these vulnerable prisoners that they are refusing to honour.” Marc Newhouse from Bandyup Action Group said the woman’s willingness to move unsegregated into the male prison population showed how desperate conditions at Bandyup had become. “Many of the women in Bandyup will have abusive partners in Hakea,” he said. “Obviously, we don’t support this suggestion.” Double-bunking in the women’s prison estate has spread to Boronia pre-release centre, WA’s flagship women’s rehabilitation facility. The Department of Corrective Services confirmed some women were “sharing rooms” at Boronia, which it said was designed to be large enough for double-occupancy, and suggested that “many female prisoners request to share a cell for companionship, peer support, wellbeing and orientation into the prison environment”. “This arrangement can be particularly beneficial for new, vulnerable or special-needs prisoners as they adapt to life in prison.” But the opposition prisons spokesman, Paul Papalia, said the justification of new, nervous prisoners did not make sense at Boronia, which is intended as a last stop for long-term prisoners to prepare them for release into the outside world. Papalia said double-bunking at Boronia also undermined one of its key features, which was to allow women to have their children to stay overnight with them. “If you’re sharing a room, obviously your children can’t stay,” he said. Papalia repeated a call for women to be moved into the privately run 80-bed Wandoo prison, a facility that is tailored to young men. That suggestion is supported by the Bandyup Action Group and the Western Australian Prison Officers’ Union. Francis has ruled out that option. Instead, the department said 30 women would move to the new Eastern Goldfields regional prison in June. The union’s secretary, John Welch, said small additions such as Eastern Goldfields were not enough to keep pace with the growth in female prisoner numbers, which have grown from 475 in March 2014 to 525 on Monday. He said concerns about interrupting the specialist program for Wandoo’s 50 or so young male prisoners – who could be moved into new units at Acacia, WA’s other Serco-run prison – should not be prioritised over the “crisis” in women’s prisons. “We are in a crisis in women’s prisons and it’s great that we can think about what’s ideal for young male prisoners, but we are not thinking in the same way about female prisoners,” he said. “We actually need to put some priority into women’s prisons for a change.” Welch said conditions at Bandyup were appalling and could lead to a higher rate of recidivism. “I’m not saying that prisons should be luxurious experiences, but they should be decent,” he said. Newhouse said pressure on prisons could be reduced immediately if the government provided the legal assistance necessary for women to use existing mechanisms – such as bail and parole – to secure their release. He said the government could also “easily” change the policy on fine defaulting to allow more outstanding fines to be served out as community service orders, rather than prison time. Instead, Francis has promised to increase the jail time required to “cut out” a fine. People with outstanding fines in WA can “cut out” the amount owed at a rate of $250 per day of jail time. Newhouse said the action group was examining the legal grounds to push for a review of all sentenced prisoners in Bandyup and a mass amnesty of low-level offences in order to deal with chronic overcrowding. He said many women in Bandyup were not dangerous and would not be there were it not for the state’s tough-on-crime laws. Guardian Australia has been told of one woman, a homeless amputee, who was charged with assaulting the police officer called to “calm her down” after someone let down the tyres of her wheelchair. Under WA law she was sentenced to a mandatory 12 months in jail for assaulting a public officer. “We have been calling for a review of mandatory sentencing laws for years, and it’s fallen on deaf ears,” Newhouse said. “They can play around with the sentences bit by bit but eventually they are going to have to change the law.” He said a whole-of-government approach was needed that would think about law and order, what is effective, and what is not.
